SubmodulesÔÉÅ

pyphyschemtools.Chem3D moduleÔÉÅ

class pyphyschemtools.Chem3D.XYZData(symbols, positions)ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

Object containing molecular coordinates and symbols extracted by molView. Allows for geometric calculations without reloading data.

get_bounding_sphere(include_vdw=True, scale=1.0)ÔÉÅ

Calculates the center and radius of the bounding sphere using ASE. scale: multiplication factor (e.g., 0.6 to match a reduced CPK style).

get_cage_volume(grid_spacing=0.5, return_spheres=False)ÔÉÅ

Calculates the internal cavity volume of a molecular cage using CageCavityCalc.

This method interfaces with the CageCavityCalc library by generating a temporary PDB file of the current structure. It can also retrieve the coordinates of the ‚Äòdummy atoms‚Äô (points) that fill the detected void.

Parameters:

  • grid_spacing (float, optional) ‚Äì The resolution of the grid used for volume integration in √Ö. Smaller values provide higher precision (default: 0.5).

  • return_spheres (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, returns both the volume and an ase.Atoms object containing the dummy atoms representing the cavity (default: False).

Returns:

  • volume (float or None) ‚Äì The calculated cavity volume in √Ö¬≥. Returns None if the calculation fails.

  • cavity_atoms (ase.Atoms, optional) ‚Äì Returned only if return_spheres is True. An ASE Atoms object representing the internal void space.

get_cavity_dimensions(cavity_atoms)ÔÉÅ

Calculates the principal dimensions (Length, Width, Height) of the cavity points.

This method uses Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to find the natural axes of the cavity, making it independent of the molecule‚Äôs orientation. Percentiles are used instead of absolute Max-Min to filter out potential outliers or ‚Äòleaking‚Äô points at the openings.

Parameters:

cavity_atoms (ase.Atoms) ‚Äì The Atoms object containing the ‚Äòdummy atoms‚Äô generated by the cavity calculation.

Returns:

The dimensions (L, W, H) sorted from largest to smallest.

Return type:

tuple (float, float, float)

get_center_of_geometry()ÔÉÅ

Calculates the arithmetic mean of the atomic positions (Centroid).

get_center_of_mass()ÔÉÅ
class pyphyschemtools.Chem3D.molView(mol, source=None, style='bs', displayHbonds=True, cpk_scale=0.6, w=600, h=400, supercell=(1, 1, 1), display_now=True, detect_BondOrders=True, viewer=True, zoom=None)ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

Initializes a molecular/crystal viewer and coordinate extractor.

This class acts as a bridge between various molecular data sources and the py3Dmol interactive viewer. It can operate in ‚ÄòFull‚Äô mode (display + analysis) or ‚ÄòHeadless‚Äô mode (analysis only) by toggling the viewer parameter.

The class automatically extracts geometric data into the self.data attribute (an XYZData object), allowing for volume, dimension, and cavity calculations.

Display molecular and crystal structures in py3Dmol from various sources:

  • XYZ/PDB/CIF local files

  • XYZ-format string

  • PubChem CID

  • ASE Atoms object

  • COD ID

  • RSCB PDB ID

Three visualization styles are available:

  • ‚Äòbs‚Äô : ball-and-stick (default)

  • ‚Äòcpk‚Äô : CPK space-filling spheres (with adjustable size)

  • ‚Äòcartoon‚Äô: protein backbone representation

Upon creation, an interactive 3D viewer is shown directly in a Jupyter notebook cell, unless the headless viewer parameter is set to False.

Parameters:

  • mol (str or ase.Atoms) ‚Äì

    The molecular structure to visualize.

    • If source=‚Äôfile‚Äô, this should be a path to a structure file (XYZ, PDB, etc.)

    • If source=‚Äômol‚Äô, this should be a string containing the structure (XYZ, PDB‚Ä¶)

    • If source=‚Äôcif‚Äô, this should be a cif file (string)

    • If source=‚Äôcid‚Äô, this should be a PubChem CID (string or int)

    • If source=‚Äôrscb‚Äô, this should be a RSCB PDB ID (string)

    • If source=‚Äôcod‚Äô, this should be a COD ID (string)

    • If source=‚Äôase‚Äô, this should be an ase.Atoms object

  • source ({'file', 'mol', 'cif', 'cid', 'rscb', 'ase'}, optional) ‚Äì The type of the input mol (default: ‚Äòfile‚Äô).

  • style ({'bs', 'cpk', 'cartoon'}, optional) ‚Äì

    Visualization style (default: ‚Äòbs‚Äô).

    • ‚Äôbs‚Äô ‚Üí ball-and-stick

    • ‚Äôcpk‚Äô ‚Üí CPK space-filling spheres

    • ‚Äôcartoon‚Äô ‚Üí draws a smooth tube or ribbon through the protein backbone

      (default for pdb structures)

  • displayHbonds (plots hydrogen bonds (default: True))

  • cpk_scale (float, optional) ‚Äì Overall scaling factor for sphere size in CPK style (default: 0.5). Ignored when style=‚Äôbs‚Äô.

  • supercell (tuple of int) ‚Äì Repetition of the unit cell (na, nb, nc). Default is (1, 1, 1).

  • w (int, optional) ‚Äì Width of the viewer in pixels (default: 600).

  • h (int, optional) ‚Äì Height of the viewer in pixels (default: 400).

  • detect_BondOrders (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True (default) and input is XYZ, uses RDKit to perceive connectivity and bond orders (detects double/triple bonds). Requires the rdkit library. If False, fallback to standard 3Dmol distance-based single bonds.

  • display_now (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True (default), renders the molecule immediately. Set to False to prevent immediate display when you plan to call further visualization methods provided by the molView class

  • viewer (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True (default), initializes the py3Dmol engine and prepares the 3D model. If False, operates in ‚Äòheadless‚Äô mode: only geometric data is processed for analysis (volume, CM, etc.), saving significant memory for high-throughput processing.

  • zoom (None, optional) ‚Äì scaling factor

dataÔÉÅ

Container for atomic symbols and positions, used for geometric analysis.

Type:

XYZData or None

vÔÉÅ

The 3Dmol.js viewer instance (None if viewer=False).

Type:

py3Dmol.view or None

Examples

>>> molView("molecule.xyz", source="file")
>>> molView(xyz_string, source="mol")
>>> molView(2244, source="cid")   # PubChem aspirin
>>> from ase.build import molecule
>>> molView(molecule("H2O"), source="ase")
>>> molView.view_grid([2244, 2519, 702], n_cols=3, source='cid', style='bs')
>>> molView.view_grid(xyzFiles, n_cols=3, source='file', style='bs', titles=titles, w=500, sync=True)
>>> # Headless mode for high-throughput volume calculations
>>> mv = molView("cage.xyz", viewer=False)
>>> vol = mv.data.get_cage_volume()
show_bounding_sphere(color='gray', opacity=0.2, scale=1.0)ÔÉÅ

Calculates and displays the VdW bounding sphere in one go.

show_cage_cavity(grid_spacing=0.5, color='cyan', opacity=0.5)ÔÉÅ

Calculates cavity with CageCavityCalc and displays it as a single model.

classmethod view_grid(mol_list, n_cols=3, titles=None, **kwargs)ÔÉÅ

Displays a list of molecular structures in an interactive n_rows x n_cols grid.

This method uses ipywidgets.GridspecLayout to organize multiple 3D viewers into a clean matrix. It automatically calculates the required number of rows based on the length of the input list.

Parameters:

  • mol_list (list) ‚Äì A list containing the molecular data to visualize. Elements should match the expected ‚Äòmol‚Äô input for the class (paths, CIDs, strings, etc.).

  • n_cols (int, optional) ‚Äì Number of columns in the grid (default: 3).

  • titles (list of str, optional) ‚Äì Custom labels for each cell. If None, the string representation of the ‚Äòmol‚Äô input is used as the title.

  • **kwargs (dict) ‚Äì Additional arguments passed to the molView constructor: - source : {‚Äòfile‚Äô, ‚Äòmol‚Äô, ‚Äòcif‚Äô, ‚Äòcid‚Äô, ‚Äòrscb‚Äô, ‚Äòase‚Äô} - style : {‚Äòbs‚Äô, ‚Äòcpk‚Äô, ‚Äòcartoon‚Äô} - displayHbonds : plots hydrogen bonds (default: True) - w : width of each individual viewer in pixels (default: 300) - h : height of each individual viewer in pixels (default: 300) - supercell : tuple (na, nb, nc) for crystal structures - cpk_scale : scaling factor for space-filling spheres

Returns:

A widget object containing the grid of molecular viewers.

Return type:

ipywidgets.GridspecLayout

Examples

>>> files = ["mol1.xyz", "mol2.xyz", "mol3.xyz", "mol4.xyz"]
>>> labels = ["Reactant", "TS", "Intermediate", "Product"]
>>> molView.view_grid(files, n_cols=2, titles=labels, source='file', w=400)

pyphyschemtools.ML.categorizeY_2ohe(Ctot, y1, y2)ÔÉÅ

one-hot-encodes a pandas column of categorical data

input: - Ctot is the reference pandas column, necessary to find all unique categories in this column - y1 and y2 are the actual pandas column that will be categorized. y1 and y2 are supposed to be the ytest and ytrain subsets of Ctot output: - y1ohe and y2ohe are the numpy arrays returned by this routine

afficher()ÔÉÅ
nomsFr = ['Hydrog√®ne', 'H√©lium', 'Lithium', 'B√©ryllium', 'Bore', 'Carbone', 'Azote', 'Oxyg√®ne', 'Fluor', 'N√©on', 'Sodium', 'Magn√©sium', 'Aluminium', 'Silicium', 'Phosphore', 'Soufre', 'Chlore', 'Argon', 'Potassium', 'Calcium', 'Scandium', 'Titane', 'Vanadium', 'Chrome', 'Mangan√®se', 'Fer', 'Cobalt', 'Nickel', 'Cuivre', 'Zinc', 'Gallium', 'Germanium', 'Arsenic', 'S√©l√©nium', 'Brome', 'Krypton', 'Rubidium', 'Strontium', 'Yttrium', 'Zirconium', 'Niobium', 'Molybd√®ne', 'Techn√©tium', 'Ruth√©nium', 'Rhodium', 'Palladium', 'Argent', 'Cadmium', 'Indium', '√âtain', 'Antimoine', 'Tellure', 'Iode', 'X√©non', 'C√©sium', 'Baryum', 'Lanthane', 'C√©rium', 'Pras√©odyme', 'N√©odyme', 'Prom√©thium', 'Samarium', 'Europium', 'Gadolinium', 'Terbium', 'Dysprosium', 'Holmium', 'Erbium', 'Thulium', 'Ytterbium', 'Lutetium', 'Hafnium', 'Tantale', 'Tungst√®ne', 'Rh√©nium', 'Osmium', 'Iridium', 'Platine', 'Or', 'Mercure', 'Thallium', 'Plomb', 'Bismuth', 'Polonium', 'Astate', 'Radon', 'Francium', 'Radium', 'Actinium', 'Thorium', 'Protactinium', 'Uranium', 'Neptunium', 'Plutonium', 'Americium', 'Curium', 'Berkelium', 'Californium', 'Einsteinium', 'Fermium', 'Mendelevium', 'Nobelium', 'Lawrencium', 'Rutherfordium', 'Dubnium', 'Seaborgium', 'Bohrium', 'Hassium', 'Meitnerium', 'Darmstadtium', 'Roentgenium', 'Copernicium', 'Nihonium', 'Flerovium', 'Moscovium', 'Livermorium', 'Tennesse', 'Oganesson']ÔÉÅ
patch_elements()ÔÉÅ

Ce patch, appliqu√© √† self.elements, cr√©√© par l‚Äôappel √† create_vis_dataframe(), va servir √† : - ajouter des informations en fran√ßais : les noms des √©l√©ments et des s√©ries (familles) auxquelles ils appartiennent - retirer les √©l√©ments du groupe 12 de la famille des m√©taux de transition, qui est le choix CONTESTABLE par d√©faut de la biblioth√®que mendeleev

input : elements est un dataframe pandas pr√©alablement cr√©√© par la fonction create_vis_dataframe() de mendeleev.vis

output : elements avec deux nouvelles colonnes name_seriesFr et nom, qui contient dor√©navant les noms des √©l√©ments en fran√ßais + correction des donn√©es name_series et series_id pour les √©l√©ments Zn, Cd, Hg, Cn + de nouvelles colonnes qui contiennent l‚Äô√©nergie de premi√®re ionisation et les isotopes naturels

pyphyschemtools.aithermo moduleÔÉÅ

class pyphyschemtools.aithermo.aiThermo(folder_path=None, color_scales=None)ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

A class to handle thermodynamic surface stability analysis and visualization within the tools4pyPhysChem framework.

ListOfStableSurfaceCompositions(vib)ÔÉÅ

Identify and list the relevant thermodynamic data files for the current analysis.

This method scans the working directory for data files matching specific naming conventions (TPcoverage or TPcoveragevib). It cross-references these with a local configuration file ‚ÄòListOfStableSurfaces.dat‚Äô to extract surface names and legend labels.

Parameters:

vib (bool) ‚Äì If True, filters for files including vibrational corrections (prefixed with vib_). If False, looks for standard thermodynamic data.

Returns:

A triplet containing: - file_paths (list of str): Absolute or relative paths to the .dat files. - names (list of str): Internal identifiers for each surface phase. - legends (list of str): LaTeX-formatted or plain text labels for graphical legends.

Return type:

tuple

Notes

  • The lists are returned in reverse order to ensure correct layering during 3D plotting.

  • Relies on ‚ÄòListOfStableSurfaces.dat‚Äô existing in the folder_path.

plot_palette(angle=0, save_png=None)ÔÉÅ

Visualize the 1D color palette used for surface identification.

This method generates a horizontal bar of colors corresponding to the different surface phases defined in the instance. Each color is labeled with its numerical index, allowing for quick cross-referencing between the palette and the 3D surface plot.

Parameters:

  • angle (int, optional) ‚Äì Rotation angle of the x-axis tick labels (indices). Defaults to 0.

  • save_png (str, optional) ‚Äì Filename (including .png extension) to save the palette image to the working directory. Defaults to None (display only).

Returns:

Displays the plot using matplotlib.pyplot.show().

Return type:

None

Notes

  • Requires ‚Äòseaborn‚Äô for the palplot generation.

  • If ‚Äòsave_png‚Äô is provided, the image is saved with a resolution of 300 DPI and a transparent background.

plot_surface(saveFig=None, vib=True, texLegend=False, xLegend=0.5, yLegend=0.4)ÔÉÅ

Generate an interactive 3D thermodynamic stability map using Plotly.

This method visualizes multiple Gibbs free energy surfaces as a function of Temperature (X) and Pressure (Y). It automatically handles log-scale transformations for the pressure axis and projects reference experimental conditions and phase boundaries onto the plot.

Parameters:

  • saveFig (str, optional) ‚Äì The filename (without extension) to export the resulting plot as a PNG image. Defaults to None (no save).

  • vib (bool) ‚Äì Whether to use vibration-corrected data. Defaults to True.

  • texLegend (bool) ‚Äì If True, uses LaTeX legends extracted from the configuration file. Defaults to False.

  • xLegend (float) ‚Äì Horizontal position of the legend box (0 to 1). Defaults to 0.5.

  • yLegend (float) ‚Äì Vertical position of the legend box (0 to 1). Defaults to 0.4.

Returns:

An interactive widget containing

the 3D surfaces, experimental markers, and reference lines.

Return type:

plotly.graph_objects.FigureWidget

Workflow:

  1. Scans data files and parses Temperature/Pressure/Energy grids.

  2. Traces individual 3D surfaces with mapped color scales.

  3. Calculates and plots intersection boundaries between surface phases.

  4. Overlays experimental markers (e.g., specific T/P conditions).

  5. Optionally exports and crops the resulting image using Pillow.

pyphyschemtools.cheminformatics moduleÔÉÅ

class pyphyschemtools.cheminformatics.easy_rdkit(smiles, canonical=True)ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

A helper class to analyze and visualize molecules using RDKit. Provides tools for Lewis structure analysis and advanced 2D drawing.

analyze_lewis()ÔÉÅ

Performs a Lewis structure analysis for each atom in the molecule. Calculates valence electrons, lone pairs, formal charges, and octet rule compliance.

Returns:

A table containing detailed Lewis electronic data per atom.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

show_mol(size: tuple = (400, 400), show_Lewis: bool = False, plot_conjugation: bool = False, plot_aromatic: bool = False, show_n: bool = False, show_hybrid: bool = False, show_H: bool = False, rep3D: bool = False, macrocycle: bool = False, highlightAtoms: list = [], legend: str = '')ÔÉÅ

Renders the molecule in 2D SVG format with optional property overlays.

Parameters:

  • size (tuple) ‚Äì Drawing dimensions in pixels.

  • show_Lewis (bool) ‚Äì Annotates atoms with Lone Pairs and Vacancies.

  • plot_conjugation (bool) ‚Äì Highlights conjugated bonds in blue.

  • plot_aromatic (bool) ‚Äì Highlights aromatic rings in red.

  • show_n (bool) ‚Äì Displays atom indices.

  • show_hybrid (bool) ‚Äì Displays atom hybridization (sp3, sp2, etc.).

  • show_H (bool) ‚Äì Adds explicit Hydrogens to the drawing.

  • rep3D (bool) ‚Äì Computes a 3D-like conformation before drawing.

  • macrocycle (bool) ‚Äì Uses CoordGen for better rendering of large rings (e.g., Cyclodextrins).

  • highlightAtoms (list) ‚Äì List of indices to highlight.

  • legend (str) ‚Äì Title or legend text for the drawing.

pyphyschemtools.core moduleÔÉÅ

pyphyschemtools.core.centerTitle(content=None)ÔÉÅ

centers and renders as HTML a text in the notebook font size = 16px, background color = dark grey, foreground color = white

pyphyschemtools.core.centertxt(content=None, font='sans', size=12, weight='normal', bgc='#000000', fgc='#ffffff')ÔÉÅ

centers and renders as HTML a text in the notebook

input: - content = the text to render (default: None) - font = font family (default: ‚Äòsans‚Äô, values allowed = ‚Äòsans-serif‚Äô | ‚Äòserif‚Äô | ‚Äòmonospace‚Äô | ‚Äòcursive‚Äô | ‚Äòfantasy‚Äô | ‚Ä¶) - size = font size (default: 12) - weight = font weight (default: ‚Äònormal‚Äô, values allowed = ‚Äònormal‚Äô | ‚Äòbold‚Äô | ‚Äòbolder‚Äô | ‚Äòlighter‚Äô | 100 | 200 | 300 | 400 | 500 | 600 | 700 | 800 | 900 ) - bgc = background color (name or hex code, default = ‚Äò#ffffff‚Äô) - fgc = foreground color (name or hex code, default = ‚Äò#000000‚Äô)

pyphyschemtools.core.crop_images(input_files, process_folder=False)ÔÉÅ

Trims whitespace or transparency from image files and saves the results.

If process_folder is True, input_files is treated as a directory path, and all images within (excluding those ending in -C) are processed. Otherwise, input_files is treated as a single file path or a list of paths.

The function preserves original image metadata (DPI, ICC profiles).

Parameters:

  • input_files (str, Path, or list) ‚Äì File path(s) or a directory path.

  • process_folder (bool) ‚Äì If True, treats input_files as a directory to crawl.

Returns:

Prints status messages to the console for each file processed.

Return type:

None

pyphyschemtools.core.smart_trim(img)ÔÉÅ

Determines the bounding box of the meaningful content in an image.

This function automatically detects if the image has transparency (Alpha channel). If it does, it calculates the bounding box based on non-transparent pixels. If the image is opaque, it assumes a white background and calculates the bounding box by detecting differences from a pure white canvas.

Parameters:

img (PIL.Image.Image) ‚Äì The source image object.

Returns:

A 4-tuple (left, upper, right, lower) defining the crop box,

or None if the image is uniform/empty.

Return type:

tuple

pyphyschemtools.kinetics moduleÔÉÅ

class pyphyschemtools.kinetics.KORD(t_exp, G_exp, headers, A0=1.0, alpha=1.0, beta=1.0, k_guess=0.01, G_0_guess=None, G_inf_guess=None, verbose=False)ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

Initialize the kinetic study with experimental data. Reaction: alpha A = beta B

Parameters:

  • t_exp (-) ‚Äì Time values.

  • G_exp (-) ‚Äì Measured physical quantity (Absorbance, Conductivity, etc.).

Fixed Parameters:

  • alpha (float): Stoichiometric coefficient for A reactant (smallest positive integer). Default is 1.0.

  • beta (float): Stoichiometric coefficient for B product (smallest positive integer). Default is 1.0.

  • A0 (float): Initial concentration. Note: G_theo is independent of A0 for Order 1. Default is 1.0.

Adjustable Variables (Initial Guesses):

  • k_guess (float, optional): Initial estimate for the rate constant. Default is 0.01.

  • G_0_guess (float, optional): Initial estimate for the initial measured value (G at t=0). if None, it will be initialized as G_exp[0]

  • G_inf_guess (float, optional): Initial estimate for the final measured value (G at infinity). if None, it will be initialized as G_exp[-1]

Other Args:

  • verbose (bool): If True, enables debug messages and detailed optimization logs.

  • headers (tuple of strings): headers of the t_exp and G_exp arrays read in the excel file

G0_theo(t, k, G0, Ginf)ÔÉÅ

Continuous linear model for optimization. Allows A(t) to be negative so curve_fit can find the gradient.

G1_theo(t, k, G0, Ginf)ÔÉÅ

Model for Order 1 kinetics

G2_theo(t, k, G0, Ginf)ÔÉÅ

Model for Order 2 kinetics

fit(k_guess, G_0_guess, G_inf_guess, order=1)ÔÉÅ

Fits the chosen kinetic model to the experimental data, with order=order (Default: 1) verbose=True: prints the initial guess vector p0

get_best_order(verbose=True)ÔÉÅ

Determines and prints the best model based on the lowest RMSD.

static load_from_excel(file_path, exp_number, sheet_name=0, show_data=True)ÔÉÅ

Static method to extract data from an Excel file. Selects the pair of columns (t, G) corresponding to the experiment number. Also loads parameters (A0, alpha, beta) Format:

Row 1: Headers for t and G Row 2: [A]0 value (in the G column) Row 3: alpha value (in the G column) Row 4: beta value (in the G column) Row 5+: [t, G] data points

plot_all_fits()ÔÉÅ

Plots experimental data and all three kinetic models for visual comparison.

pyphyschemtools.spectra moduleÔÉÅ

class pyphyschemtools.spectra.SpectrumSimulator(sigma_ev=0.3, plotWH=(12, 8), fontSize_axisText=14, fontSize_axisLabels=14, fontSize_legends=12, fontsize_peaks=12, colorS='#3e89be', colorVT='#469cd6')ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

plotAbs_lambda_TDDFT(datFiles=None, C0=1e-05, lambdamin=200, lambdamax=800, Amax=2.0, titles=None, linestyles=[], annotateP=[], tP=0.1, resetColors=False, filename=None)ÔÉÅ

Plots a simulated TDDFT VUV absorbance spectrum (transitions summed with gaussian functions) between lambdamin and lambdamax (sum of states done in the range [lambdamin-50, lambdamlax+50] nm)

Parameters:

  • datFiles ‚Äì list of pathway/name to files generated by ‚ÄòGParser Gaussian.log -S‚Äô

  • C0 ‚Äì list of concentrations needed to calculate A = epsilon x l x c (in mol.L-1)

  • lambdamin ‚Äì plot range (x axis)

  • lambdamax ‚Äì plot range (x axis)

  • Amax ‚Äì y axis graph limit

  • titles ‚Äì list of titles (1 per spectrum plot)

  • linestyles ‚Äì list of line styles(default = ‚Äú-‚Äù, i.e. a continuous line)

  • annotateP ‚Äì list of Boolean (annotate lambda max True or False. Default = True)

  • tP ‚Äì threshold for finding the peaks (default = 0.1)

  • resetColors (bool) ‚Äì If True, resets the matplotlib color cycle to the first color. This allows different series (e.g., gas phase vs. solvent) to share the same color coding for each molecule across multiple calls. Default: False

  • save ‚Äì saves in a png file (300 dpi) if True (default = False)

  • filename ‚Äì saves figure in a 300 dpi png file if not None (default), with filename=full pathway

plotAbs_lambda_exp(csvFiles, C0, lambdamin=200, lambdamax=800, Amax=2.0, titles=None, linestyles=[], annotateP=[], tP=0.1, filename=None)ÔÉÅ

Plots an experimental VUV absorbance spectrum read from a csv file between lambdamin and lambdamax

Parameters:

  • superpose (-) ‚Äì False = plots a new graph, otherwise the plot is superposed to a previously created one (probably with plotAbs_lambda_TDDFT())

  • csvfiles (-) ‚Äì list of pathway/name to experimental csvFiles (see examples for the format)

  • C0 (-) ‚Äì list of experimental concentrations, i.e. for each sample

  • lambdamin (-) ‚Äì plot range (x axis)

  • lambdamax ‚Äì plot range (x axis)

  • Amax (-) ‚Äì graph limit (y axis)

  • titles (-) ‚Äì list of titles (1 per spectrum plot)

  • linestyles (-) ‚Äì list of line styles(default = ‚Äú‚Äì‚Äù, i.e. a dashed line)

  • annotateP (-) ‚Äì list of Boolean (annotate lambda max True or False. Default = True)

  • tP (-) ‚Äì threshold for finding the peaks (default = 0.1)

  • save (-) ‚Äì saves in a png file (300 dpi) if True (default = False)

  • filename (-) ‚Äì saves figure in a 300 dpi png file if not None (default), with filename=full pathway

plotEps_lambda_TDDFT(datFile, lambdamin=200, lambdamax=800, epsMax=None, titles=None, tP=10, ylog=False, filename=None)ÔÉÅ

Plots a TDDFT VUV simulated spectrum (vertical transitions and transitions summed with gaussian functions) between lambdamin and lambdamax

The sum of states is done in the range [lambdamin-50, lambdamax+50] nm.

Parameters:

  • datFile ‚Äì list of pathway/names to ‚ÄúXXX_ExcStab.dat‚Äù files generated by ‚ÄòGParser Gaussian.log -S‚Äô

  • lambdamin ‚Äì plot range

  • lambdamax ‚Äì plot range

  • epsMax ‚Äì y axis graph limit

  • titles ‚Äì list of titles (1 per spectrum plot)

  • tP ‚Äì threshold for finding the peaks (default = 10 L. mol-1 cm-1)

  • ylog ‚Äì y logarithmic axis (default: False).

  • save ‚Äì saves in a png file (300 dpi) if True (default = False)

  • filename ‚Äì saves figure in a 300 dpi png file if not None (default), with filename=full pathway

plotTDDFTSpectrum(wavel, sumInt, wavelTAB, feTAB, tP, ylog, labelSpectrum, colorS='#0000ff', colorT='#0000cf')ÔÉÅ

Called by plotEps_lambda_TDDFT. Plots a single simulated UV-Vis spectrum, i.e. after gaussian broadening, together with the TDDFT vertical transitions (i.e. plotted as lines)

Parameters:

  • wavel ‚Äì array of gaussian-broadened wavelengths, in nm

  • sumInt ‚Äì corresponding molar absorptiopn coefficients, in L. mol-1 cm-1

  • wavelTAB ‚Äì wavelength of TDDFT, e.g. discretized, transitions

  • ylog ‚Äì log plot of epsilon

  • tP ‚Äì threshold for finding the peaks

  • feTAB ‚Äì TDDFT oscillator strength for each transition of wavelTAB

  • labelSpectrum ‚Äì title for the spectrum
